resources.string:
EP Mobile is a package of useful cardiac electrophysiology tools for your Android phone or tablet. These tools are for reference purposes only and are not meant to substitute for clinical judgment. If you have suggestions or comments, please contact us. 

Email: mannd@epstudiossoftware.com 
Web: www.epstudiossoftware.com 
Source: github.com/mannd/epmobile 

Copyright © 2011-2019 EP Studios, Inc. 
Licensed under GNU GPL v3.
Use RR Interval or Heart Rate
Use RR interval or heart rate as default
Enter the maximum QTc in msec
This value in msec is used to color code (with red) abnormally high QTc values
Abnormal renal function (dialysis, kidney transplant, Cr \u2267 2.6 mg/dL)
Labile INRs (high INRs, or <60% of time in therapeutic range)
Alcohol intake (8 or more drinks per week)
Aspirin or anticoagulation (warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban) is recommended.
Anticoagulation (warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban) is recommended.
Current guidelines recommend using CHA\u2082DS\u2082-VASc rather than CHADS\u2082 to assess stroke risk, especially when CHADS\u2082 is 0 or 1.
Vascular disease (e.g. PVD, CAD, aortic plaque)
No anticoagulation or anticoagulation (warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban) or aspirin may be considered (2014 AHA/ACC/HRS guidelines).
Anticoagulation (warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban or edoxaban) is recommended.
European Society of Cardiology (2012) recommends no anticoagulation when female sex is the only risk factor.
European Society of Cardiology (2012) recommends anticoagulation.
Select the default warfarin tablet strength
Reference: Horton J, Bushwick B: American Family Physician. Feb 1, 1999. http://www.aafp.org/afp/990201ap/635.html
Absence of an RS complex in all precordial leads?
R to S interval > 100 msec in one precordial lead?
Morphology criteria for VT present in both precordial leads V1-2 and V6?
Wide complex tachycardia is most likely Ventricular Tachycardia.
Wide complex tachycardia is most likely Supraventricular Tachycardia.
Reference: Brugada P, et al. Circ 1991;83:1649.
R > 30 msec in V1 or V2
Onset to nadir S > 60 msec in V1 or V2
Notched or slurred S in V1 or V2
R to S ratio < 1 in V6

R wave peak time in lead II (RWPT). Measure the onset of the QRS in ECG lead II to the first change in polarity (nadir Q or peak R). RWPT \u2265 50 msec strongly suggests VT (positive likelihood ratio 34.8). Reference: Pava LF, et al. Heart Rhythm 2010;7:922.
From Wellens et al. Am J Med 1978;64:27.
Refractory Periods and Block Cycle Lengths
Reference: Josephson ME. Clinical Cardiac Electrophysiology. Techniques and Interpretations. 2nd Edition 1993. Lea & Febiger.
I. Global or regional dysfunction and structural alterations
Regional RV akinesia, dyskinesia, or aneurysm
Regional RV akinesia or dyssynchronous RV contraction
and one of the following (end diastole)…
PLAX RVOT \u2265 32 mm (corrected for body size [PLAX/BSA] \u2265 19 mm/m\u00b2)
PSAX RVOT \u2265 36 mm (corrected for body size [PSAX/BSA] \u2265 21 mm/m\u00b2)
PLAX RVOT \u2265 29 to \u003c 32 mm (corrected for body size [PLAX/BSA] \u2265 16 to \u003c 19 mm/m\u00b2)
PSAX RVOT \u2265 32 to \u003c 36mm (corrected for body size [PSAX/BSA] \u2265 18 to \u003c 21 mm/m\u00b2)
Ratio of RV end-diastolic volume to BSA \u2265 110 mL/m\u00b2 (male) or \u2265 100 mL/m\u00b2 (female)
Ratio of RV end-diastolic volume to BSA \u2265 100 to \u003c 110 mL/m\u00b2 (male) or \u2265 90 to \u003c 100 mL/m\u00b2 (female)

Residual myocytes \u003c 60% by morphometric analysis (or \u003c 50% if estimated) with fibrous replacement of RV free wall myocardium in \u2265 1 sample, with or without fatty replacement of tissue on endomyocardial biopsy

Residual myocytes 60% to 75% by morphometric analysis (or 50% to 65% if estimated) with fibrous replacement of RV free wall myocardium in \u2265 1 sample, with or without fatty replacement of tissue on endomyocardial biopsy
TWI (V1, V2, and V3) or beyond in individuals \u003e 14 yrs (in absence of complete RBBB)
TWI in V1 and V2 in individuals \u003e 14 yrs (in absence of complete RBBB) or in V4, V5, V6
TWI in V1-V4 in individuals \u003e 14 yrs in presence of complete RBBB
Epsilon wave (reproducible low-amp signals between end of QRS complex to onset of T wave) in right precordial leads (V1-V3)
LP by SAECG in \u2265 1 of 3 parameters in absence of QRS duration of \u2265 110 msec on standard ECG
Duration of terminal QRS \u003c 40 \u03bcV (low-amplitude signal duration) \u2265 38 msec
Terminal activation duration of QRS \u2265 55 msec measured from the nadir of the S wave to the end of the QRS including R\', in V1, V2, or V3, in the absence of complete RBBB
Nonsustained or sustained VT of LBBB morphology with superior axis (negative or indeterminate QRS in leads II, III, and aVF and positive in lead aVL)
Nonsustained or sustained VT of RV outflow configuration, LBBB morphology with inferior axis (positive QRS in leads II, III, and aVF and negative in lead aVL) or of unknown axis
ARVC/D confirmed in a first-degree relative who meets current Task Force criteria
ARVC/D confirmed pathologically at autopsy or surgery in a first-degree relative
Identification of a pathogenic mutation categorized as associated or probably associated with ARVC/D in the patient under evaluation
History of ARVC/D in a first-degree relative in whom it is not possible or practical to determine whether the family member meets current Task Force criteria
Premature sudden death (\u003c 35 years of age) due to suspected ARVC/D in a first-degree relative
ARVC/D confirmed pathologically or by current Task Force Criteria in a second-degree relative
BSA = body surface area. PLAX = parasternal long axis view. PSAX = parasternal short axis view. RVOT = RV outflow tract.
Reference: Marcus FI et al. Circulation 2010;121:1533. http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/121/13/1533.long
Avoid concomitant use of P-gp inhibitors (e.g. dronedarone).
Consider reducing dose of dabigatran to 75 mg twice a day when dronedarone or systemic ketoconazole is administered with dabigatran.
There may be increased bleeding risk at age over 75 years.
1st or 2nd degree relative with sudden death
Mutation of undetermined significance in a culprit gene
Gollob M, et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 2011;57:802.

Electrocardiogram must be recorded in the absence of modifiers known to shorten the QT. Jpoint-Tpeak interval must be measured in the precordial lead with the greatest amplitude T-wave. Clinical history: events must occur in the absence of an identifiable etiology, including structural heart disease. Note that at least one ECG manifestation must be present in order to get additional points.
Survivors of cardiac arrest and patients with spontaneous sustained VT are considered at very high risk for SD and are ICD candidates
Patients with 2 or more major risk factors are considered at high risk and should be considered for ICD implantation.

Patients with 1 major risk factor have increased risk for SD and recommendations should be individualized. Factors such as the nature of the risk factor (e.g. SD in an immediate family member with HCM), young age (which confers greater risk) and presence of minor risk factors should be considered. ICD implantation can be considered depending on these factors.
Patients without any major risk factors (even if minor risk factors are present) are considered to be at low risk for SD. ICD implantation is not recommended.

BP = blood pressure. VF = ventricular fibrillation. VT = ventricular tachycardia. SD = unexpected sudden death. Abnormal exercise BP = failure to augment and maintain systolic BP \u003e 25 mm Hg with exercise.
References: Maron B et al. Eur Heart J 2003:1965. http://eurheartj.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/21/1965.full McKenna WJ et al. Heart 2002;87:169. http://heart.bmj.com/content/87/2/169.full
Documented CA due to VF, without transient or reversible cause
Documented sustained VT/VF, either spontaneous or induced at EPS, not associated with an acute MI, and without transient or reversible cause
Documented familial or inherited condition with a high risk of life-threatening VT, including, but not limited to, Long QT Syndrome or HCM
Not clinically stable (e.g. in shock, from any etiology)
CABG or PCI within past 3 months
Symptoms or findings that would make patient a candidate for revascularization
SVT, e.g. AF, with poorly controlled ventricular rate
Non-cardiac disease with likelihood of survival \u003c 1 year
You must select a NYHA class.
ICD implantation appears to meet CMS guidelines.
ICD implantation does NOT meet CMS guidelines.
There are one or more absolute exclusions to ICD implantation.

Select patient characteristics and then select Calculate to show whether the patient is likely to meet CMS guidelines for Medicare reimbursement. Note the CMS National Coverage Determination (NCD) is quite detailed and you should be very familiar with it before making a decision as to whether a particular patient is covered. This module is only intended as a guide to the NCD and is not definitive. The module has been updated to the latest 2018 CMS guidelines.

AF = atrial fibrillation. CA = cardiac arrest. CABG = coronary artery bypass grafting. CM = cardiomyopathy. CMS = Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. EF = ejection fraction. EPS = electrophysiology study. HCM = hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. ICD = implantable cardioverter defibrillator. OMT = optimal medical therapy. MI = myocardial infarction. NYHA = New York Heart Association. PCI = percutaneous coronary intervention. SVT = supraventricular tachycardia. VT = ventricular tachycardia/tachyarrhythmia. VF = ventricular fibrillation.
Reference: CMS: Decision Memo for Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (CAG-00157R4) Feb 15, 2018. https://www.cms.gov/medicare-coverage-database/details/nca-decision-memo.aspx?NCAId=288
Shared decision making encounter using evidence-based decision tool necessary prior to ICD implant.
Gage BF et al. Am Heart J 2006;151:713
Hepatic (cirrhosis, \u2265 2-fold elevation of AST or ALT, or albumin < 3.6 g/dL) or renal disease (Cr clearance < 30 mL/min)
Ethanol use (history of EtOH abuse, recent hospitalization for EtOH-related illness, and worsening liver disease
Reduced platelet count or function (plts < 75,000, scheduled use of antiplatelet therapy, i.e. daily ASA or NSAID Rx, or blood dyscrasia)
Hypertension, uncontrolled (BP not currently controlled, systolic BP \u2265 160)
Anemia (most recent Hct < 30 or Hgb < 10 g/dL)
Elevated risk of fall including neuropsychiatric disease (Alzheimer, Parkinson, schizophrenia, etc.)

Note this algorithm uses polarity of initial delta wave (positive +, negative -, or isoelectric ±)

Lead I delta ± or -
 or V1 R/S ≥ 1?
Pathway is Left Free Wall\nLead aVF delta + ?
Pathway is Left Free Wall\nLead I delta \u00b1 or Lead V1 S \u00b1 ?
Pathway is Right Free Wall\nLead aVF delta + ?
Left Posterior or Posteroseptal Tricuspid Annulus
Epicardial: Coronary Sinus or Middle Cardiac Vein
Posteroseptal Tricuspid Annulus or Posteroseptal Mitral Annulus
Q or isoelectric delta wave in Leads I, aVL, or V6?
LBBB (+ QRS \u2265 90 msec in Lead I and rS in V1 and V2)?
Q or isoelectric delta wave two of Leads II, III, aVF?
Rs or RS in V1, V2, or V3?
Rs or RS in V1 or V2?
QTc 4th min of recovery from exercise stress test \u2265 480 msec
Unexplained SCD \u003c age 30 in immediate family

ECG findings in absence of medications that affect ECG, LQTS = long QT syndrome, QTc calculated by Bazett formula, SCD = sudden cardiac death, *resting heart rate below 2nd percentile for age. Note: the same family member cannot be counted more than once.
Severe dilatation and reduction of RVEF with no or only mild LV impairment
Localized RV aneurysms (akinetic or dyskinetic areas with diastolic bulging)
Severe segmental dilatation of the RV
Mild global RV dilatation and/or EF reduction with normal LV
Mild segmental dilatation of the RV
Fibrofatty replacement of myocardium on endomyocardial biopsy
T wave inversion in leads V2 and V3, with age \u003e 12 yrs, in absence of RBBB
Epsilon waves or localized prolongation (> 110 msec) of QRS complex in leads V1 to V3
Sustained or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia with LBBB morphology on ECG, Holter or treadmill test
Familial ARVC/D confirmed at autopsy or surgery
Family history of sudden death (< 35 yrs) due to suspected ARVC/D
Family history of ARVC/D based on these criteria
Reference: McKenna WJ et al. Br Heart J. 1994;71:215. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/ppmc/articles/PMC483655/
S in V1 + R in V5 or V6
S in V3 + R in aVL (men)
S in V3 + R in aVL (women)
R in I, II, III, or aVF
LVH present if any of above voltage criteria met.
Reference: Hsieh BP et al. Am Heart J 2005;150:161.
Any limb-lead R or S \u2265 20 mm or S V1 or V2 \u2265 30 mm or R V5 or V6 \u2265 30 mm
Left ventricular strain pattern without digitalis
Left ventricular strain pattern with digitalis
Intrinsicoid QRS deflection of \u2265 50 msec in V5 or V6
Left ventricular strain = ST-J point depression \u2265 1 mm and inverted T wave in lead V5. Left atrial enlargement = P terminal force in V1 \u2265 1 mm deep and \u2265 40 msec wide.

Frequency: 30-35%
Locus: 11p15.5
Gene: KVLQT1 (KCNQ1)
Channel: IKs
ECG: Broad T wave
Features: Episodes with stress, exercise, swimming, diving; failure of QT to shorten with exercise

Frequency: 25-30%
Locus: 7q35-36
Gene: HERG
Channel: IKr
ECG: Split or low amplitude late T wave
Features: Triggered by loud noises, alarms

Frequency: 5-10%
Locus: 3p21-24
Gene: SCN5A
Channel: INa
ECG: Late onset biphasic or peaked T wave
Features: Associated with bradycardia

Frequency: 1-2%
Locus: 4q25-27
Gene: ANKB
Channel: INaKATP, INaCa exchange
ECG: Variable QT prolongation
Features: No specific features

Remaining subtypes all <1% frequency (some just single families) without distinguishing features. One exception is LQTS 8 which affects the ICaL channel, has alternating T waves on ECG, and is associated with Timothy Syndrome.

Type 1: Coved ST elevation with ≥ 2 mm J-point elevation and gradually descending ST segment followed by negative T wave. Considered diagnostic of Brugada syndrome if occurs spontaneously or induced by drug challenge.

Type 2: Saddle back pattern with ≥ 2 mm J-point elevation and ≥ 1 mm ST elevation with a positive or biphasic T wave. Occasionally seen in healthy subjects.

Type 3: Saddle back pattern with < 2 mm J point elevation and < 1 mm ST elevation with positive T wave. Not uncommon in healthy subjects.
You have selected strain pattern with and without digitalis. Please select one or the other, not both.

Pseudo-delta wave (Δ): Measured from earliest ventricular activation to the earliest fast deflection in any precordial lead. Pseudo-delta wave ≥ 34 msec predicts epicardial origin (Sens 83%, Spec 95%).

Intrinsicoid deflection time (ID): Measured from earliest ventricular activation to the peak of the R wave in V2. ID of ≥ 85 msec predicts epicardial origin (Sens 87%, Spec 90%).

Shortest RS complex (RS): Measured from the earliest ventricular activation to the nadir of the first S wave in any precordial lead. RS ≥ 121 msec predicts epicardial origin (Sens 76%, Spec 85%).

Reference: http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/109/15/1842.full
QRS transition (first precordial lead with R > S) V4 or later?
QRS duration \u2265 140 msec or R wave notching in inferior leads?
Negative or isoelectric QRS in I?
Positive or isoelectric QRS in aVL?
VT location may be right or left sided. Select RV to find predicted RV location, LV to find predicted LV location.
Absent S in V5 or V6?

\nSupravalvular (aortic cusp) Location.\nTransition is in V2 or V3 with origin in the right coronary cusp, and in V1 or V2 in the left coronary cusp. Left coronary cusp VT is often associated with a W- or M-shaped pattern in V1.
\nSubvalvular Location.\nVT from the aorto-mitral continuity often has a qR pattern in V1. VT from the mitral annulus has an R in V1.

Ventricular tachycardia and premature ventricular complexes can arise from either the right or left ventricular outflow tract (RVOT or LVOT). Outflow tract VT has a vertical axis and a left bundle branch block pattern in the precordial leads. The earlier the precordial transition lead, the more likely the VT is from the LVOT. If the precordial transition is in lead V3 it is not possible to use an algorithm to determine from which ventricle the VT arises. See Tanner et al. JACC 2005;45:418. http://content.onlinejacc.org/cgi/content/short/45/3/418. \nThis algorithm was developed from Joshi S and Wilber DJ, J Cardiovasc Electrophysiol 2005;16:Suppl I:S52, Bala R and Marchlinski FE, Heart Rhythm 2007;4:366, and Srivathsan K et al. Indian Pacing Electrophysiol J 2005;5:106. http://cogprints.org/4219/1/srivathsan.htm

Use this module to predict the location of idiopathic mitral annular ventricular tachycardia or premature ventricular complexes based on the ECG. Note that this module does not deal with mitral isthmus VT in the setting of inferior infarction (see Wilber D et al. Circulation 1995;92:3481 http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/92/12/3481.long) Reference: Tada H et al. JACC 2005;45:877.
Precordial transition (first precordial lead with R > S) in V1 or V2 with R or Rs pattern in V2 to V5 (R/S > 3 in V2-V4)?
Notching of R wave in inferior leads?
Notching of Q wave in inferior leads, no Q or S wave in V1, and transition in V1?
QRS morphology suggests VT or PVCs are NOT arising from the mitral annulus

This is the recommended starting dose for treatment of atrial fibrillation. Initial QT should be < 450 msec (package insert specifies QT, not QTc). If QT remains < 500 msec dose can be increased to 120 mg or 160

This calculator can be used to adjust the warfarin dose when a patient is on a stable weekly dosing schedule. It should not be used when first starting warfarin. Select the tablet dose the patient uses and the target INR. Enter the measured INR and the total number of mg the patient is taking per week (e.g. a patient taking 5 mg daily takes 5 x 7 = 35 mg of warfarin per week). The calculator will determine the percentage weekly dose increase or decrease that is likely to bring the INR back into the target range. When it is feasible, the calculator will suggest the number of tablets to take each day of the week to achieve the INR goal. An upper and lower range of dosing will be given; in some cases, when dosing changes are small, the upper and lower range will be identical. When there is a range of doses, you might decide to use the higher or lower dose depending on other factors, such as the patient\'s previous response to dosing changes or the patient\'s age. Warfarin dosing is not an exact science!
Use 2.5 mg twice daily when administered with strong dual inhibitors of CYP3A4 and P-gp.
Avoid coadministration with strong dual inhibitors of CYP3A4 and P-gp.
Pediatric dosing is not recommended or not calculated. by EP Mobile.
P Wave Morphology in Lead V1?
Right Side of Septum or Perinodal
Coronary Sinus Os or Left Side of Septum
Tricuspid Annulus or Right Atrial Appendage
Left Sided Pulmonary Vein or Left Atrial Appendage
Crista Terminalis or Right Sided Pulmonary Vein
P Wave in Leads V2–4 Positive?
Bifid P in II and/or V1?
Negative P in All Inferior Leads?
Kistler et al. JACC 2006;48:1010. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2006;48(5):1010-1017. http://content.onlinejacc.org/article.aspx?articleid=1137857

This algorithm applies only to focal atrial tachycardia. To be accurate, the P wave must have a discrete isoelectric segment before its start, i.e. don\'t use a P wave that is fused onto the end of a T wave. Iso means isoelectric, defined as a < 0.05 mV deviation from the baseline. The algorithm sensitivity in the original study was 93%.
90 Days (ICD OK s/p revasc or NICM)

This Entrainment Mapping module is most suited for mapping ischemic ventricular tachycardia (VT), but principles of entrainment apply to all reentrant arrhythmias. Entrainment is performed by pacing during stable VT (or other reentrant tachycardia) for approximately 8-15 beat trains at 20-40 msec shorter than the tachycardia cycle length (TCL). Make sure all electrograms are "entrained", i.e. the CL shortens to the pacing CL. The post-pacing interval (PPI) is measured from the last pacing stimulus to the next electrogram recorded from the pacing site. Concealed fusion is present if the tachycardia morphology does not change during entrainment. If there is concealed fusion then the pacing site is in an area of slow conduction near the critical isthmus of the reentry circuit. During VT if a discrete electrogram (EG) is present prior to the QRS onset then the EG-QRS interval can be measured. During entrainment with concealed fusion, if there is a delay between the pacing stimulus to onset of the QRS (S-QRS), then the site is within the critical isthmus if the S-QRS interval is similar to the EG-QRS interval. In addition the relative location within the critical isthmus can be estimated by the ratio of the S-QRS to the TCL. Sites with concealed fusion but long PPI intervals are probably adjacent bystander tracts. Pacing sites within the critical isthmus are associated with a much higher chance of successful tachycardia termination with ablation than other sites.
Inner loop or isthmus site of reentry circuit.
Adjacent bystander pathway not in reentry circuit.
Similar S-QRS and EG-QRS intervals suggest site in isthmus of reentry circuit.
Dissimilar S-QRS and EG-QRS intervals suggest site may be an adjacent bystander.
Actual weight is at least 30% over Ideal Body Weight. Recommended weight is Adjusted Body Weight (
These measurements may not be useful when height is < 60 inches.
Actual weight is less than Ideal Body Weight. Recommended weight is Actual Weight (
Weight is in the normal range. Recommended weight is Ideal Body Weight (
Abnormal ECG (new changes or non-sinus rhythm)
No or little risk of serious events at 30 days.
Risk of serious events at 30 days (98% sensitive and 56% specific).
Quinn J et al. Ann Emerg Med 2006 47:448
Martin TP et al. Ann Emerg Med 1997 29:459
Colivicchi F et al. Eur Heart J 2003 24:811
Predisposing and/or precipitating factors (warm-crowded place, prolonged standing, fear, pain, emotion)
Del Rosso A et al. Heart 2008 94:1630
Initial r or q in aVR with width > 40 msec?
Notching on the initial downstroke of a predominantly negative QRS complex in aVR?
Ratio of voltage of initial and final 40 msec of QRS complex in aVR (Vi/Vt) \u2264 1?
Reference: Vereckei A et al. Heart Rhythm 2008 5:89.
Reference: Dodson JA et al. JACC 2014 8:788.\n

Note that this algorithm uses QRS polarity, not delta wave polarity!\n\n Polarity of QRS in Lead V1 is + or \u00b1 ?
Lead III has Qrs pattern\n (deep Q followed by small r and s in a negative QRS complex in lead III)?
\nMore information can be found in the Drug Reference modules.
\nDoses calculated here are only for the nonvalvular atrial fibrillation indication.
\nUse with caution in patients with ESRD on dialysis

Age = age at evaluation. Wall thickness = maximum left ventricular wall thickness. Note all echo measurements via transthoracic echo. LA (left atrial) diameter measured in parasternal long axis. Gradient = maximum left ventricular outflow tract gradient determined at rest and with Valsalva using pulsed and continuous wave Doppler from the apical 3 and 5 chamber views. Peak outflow gradients determined by modified Bernoulli equation: Gradient = 4V\u00B2, where V is the peak aortic outflow velocity. Family hx of SCD = history of sudden cardiac death in 1 or more first degree relatives under 40 years old or in a first degree relative with confirmed HCM at any age. NSVT = nonsustained ventricular tachycardia: 3 consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of 120 bpm or more and <30 sec duration on Holter monitoring (minimum 24 hrs) at or prior to evaluation.

References: Elliott PM et al. 2014 ESC guidelines on diagnosis and management of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Eur Heart J 2014;35:2733, http://eurheartj.oxfordjournals.org/content/35/39/2733#sec-16 O\'Mahony C et al. Eur Heart J 2014;35:2010, http://eurheartj.oxfordjournals.org/content/35/30/2010.long
One or more entries are invalid.
Age must be between 16 and 115 yrs.
Maximum LV wall thickness must be between 10 and 35 mm.
Maximum LV gradient must be between 2 and 154 mmHg.
Maximum LA diameter must be between 28 and 67 mm.

O\'Mahony C., Jichi F., Pavlou M., Monserrat L., Anastasakis A., Rapezzi C. A novel clinical risk prediction model for sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM Risk-SCD). Eur Heart J [Internet] 2014 Aug [cited 2015 May 29];35(30):2010–2020. Available from: http://doi.org/10.1093/eurheartj/eht439
Severe renal disease (GFR <30 mL/min or hemodialysis)

Fang MC, Go, AS, Chang Y, Borowsky LH, Pomernacki NK, Udaltsova N, Singer DE. A new risk scheme to predict warfarin-associated hemorrhage. The ATRIA Study. J Am Coll Cardiol [Internet]. 2011 Jul 2011 [cited 2015 Nov 29];58(4):395-401. Available from: http://content.onlinejacc.org/article.aspx?articleid=1146658
Low bleeding risk on warfarin (hemorrhage rate 0.8% per year).
Intermediate bleeding risk on warfarin (hemorrhage rate 2.6% per year). Consider alternatives to warfarin.
High bleeding risk on warfarin (hemorrhage rate 5.8% per year). Strongly consider alternatives to warfarin.
Singer DE et al. J Am Heart Assoc 2013 2:e000250

Singer DE, Chang Y, Borowsky LH, Fang MC, Pomernacki NK, Udaltsova N, Reynolds K, Go AS. A new risk scheme to predict ischemic stroke and other thromboembolism in atrial fibrillation: the ATRIA study stroke risk score. J Am Heart Assoc [Internet]. 2013 Jun 19 [cited 2015 Nov 29];2:e000250. Available from: http://jaha.ahajournals.org/content/2/3/e000250
Moderate thromboembolic risk (1 to <2% per year).
High thromboembolic risk (2% or greater per year).
Medical hx (> 2 of HTN, DM, CAD/MI, PAD, CHF, prior stroke, pulmonary disease, and hepatic or renal disease)

Apostolakis S, Sullivan RM, Olshansky B, Lip GYH. Factors affecting quality of anticoagulation control among patients with atrial fibrillation on warfarin. The SAMe-TT\u2082R\u2082 Score. Chest [Internet]. 2013 Nov [cited 2015 Dec 2] 144(5):1555-1563. Available from: http://journal.publications.chestnet.org/article.aspx?articleid=1686270
Patient likely to have good anticoagulation control on warfarin with high (\u226565%) TTR (Time in Therapeutic Range).

Patient likely to have poor anticoagulation control on warfarin with low (<65%) TTR (Time in Therapeutic Range). Improve education regarding anticoagulation control, or consider a new oral anticoagulant instead of warfarin.
Anemia or hx anemia (Hgb < 13 mg/dL male, < 12 mg/dL female>

preLBBB QTc only defined for LBBB

QT = %d msec.

Use: The QT varies with heart rate, QRS and sex, and so is usually not a good measure of repolarization independent of these other factors.

Formula: This is the uncorrected QT interval.

Normal values: Not defined

QTc = %1$d msec.

Use: The QTc corrects for heart rate, in this case using the Bazett formula, but does not correct for increased QRS duration. 

Formula: QTc[sec] = QT[sec] / SQRT(RR[sec])

Normal values (without IVCD) per AHA/ACC/HRS guidelines (%2$s): Male < 450 msec, Female < 460 msec and > 390 msec (both sexes)
Select any of the results in the list to see a dialog with detailed results
Bogossian H et al. New formula for evaluation of the QT interval in patients with left bundle branch block. Heart Rhythm 2004;11:2273-2277.
QTrr,qrs = QT - 155 x (60/HR - 1) - 0.93 x (QRS - 139) + k, k = -22 ms for men and -34 ms for women
Rautaharju P et al. Assessment of prolonged QT and JT intervals in ventricular conduction defects. Amer J Cardio 2003;93:1017-1021.
QT Corrected for Rate,\nQRS, and Sex (QTrr,qrs)

JT = %d msec.

Use: The JT interval corrects for QRS duration, but does not correct for heart rate. 

Formula: JT = QT - QRS

Normal values: Not defined.

JTc = %d msec.

Use: JTc corrects for heart rate and QRS duration, however normal values are not well established. 

Formula: JTc = QTc(Bazett) - QRS

Normal values: Not defined.

QTm = %1$d msec.

Use: Attempts to correct for the prolongation of the QT interval attributable to QRS prolongation in LBBB. 

Formula: QTm = QTb - 0.485 * QRSb

Normal values: Not defined.

Reference: %2$s

QTmc = %1$d msec.

Use: Corrects QTm for heart rate, in this case using the Bazett formula.

Formula: QTmc = QTm corrected for rate using Bazett formula

Normal values: Presumably the same as QTc.

Reference: %2$s

QTrr,qrs = %1$d msec.

Use: Corrects QT for rate, QRS duration and sex.

Formula: %2$s

Normal values: 2%% and 5%% normal limits of 460 and 450 msec.

Reference: %3$s

Results based on MADIT-II study population, in brief, EF \u2264 30%%, prior MI, excluding NYHA class IV, recent MI/CABG, renal failure and others.

Fever-induced type 1 Brugada ECG pattern at nominal or high leads
Type 2 or 3 Brugada ECG pattern that converts with provocative drug challenge
Unexplained arrest or documented VF/polymorphic VT
Atrial flutter/fibrillation in patients < 30 years without alternative etiology
First- or second-degree relative with definite Brugada Syndrome
Suspicious SCD (fever, nocturnal, Brugada aggravating drugs) in first- or second-degree relative
Unexplained SCD < 45 years in first- or second-degree relative with negative autopsy
Probable pathogenic mutation in Brugada susceptibility gene

Dynamic changes in J-point elevation (≥ 0.1 mV) in ≥ 2 inferior and/or lateral leads
≥ 0.1 mV J-point elevation in at least 2 inferior and/or lateral ECG leads
≥ 2 first-degree relatives with a IIa ECG pattern as above
First-degree relative with a IIa ECG pattern as above
Short-coupled PVCs with R on ascending limb or peak of T wave
ER = Early repolarization. PVCs = Premature ventricular complexes VF = ventricular fibrillation. VT = ventricular tachycardia. SCD = sudden cardiac death.

Note that all ICD candidates must have left ventricular EF measured by echocardiography, radionuclide (nuclear medicine) imaging, cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or catheter angiography. Select an EF range and try again.
No ICD indications have been selected. Use the checkboxes to select an indication.
Waiting periods (CABG or PCI within 3 months, MI within 40 days) do not apply in this circumstance.
Not enough information to determine if ICD is indicated.

It is necessary to delay implantation until waiting period expires (40 days post-MI, 3 months post CABG or PCI). Note that if a pacemaker is indicated or the patient has an ICD at ERI or with lead/device malfunction, ICD implantation CAN proceed before waiting period expires.
ICD implantation doesn\'t meet criteria due to excluson or waiting period.
Coverage of ICDs as a bridge to transplant is determined by local Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs).

* in the absence of medications affecting heart rate, hypothyroidism and uremia. IVC = inferior vena cava, PE = pericardial effusion, SBP = systolic blood pressure. Contraindications to pericardiocentesis include uncorrected coagulopathy, INR > 1.5, thrombocytopenia < 50,000/mm\u00b3, small, posterior, and loculated effusions, or effusions resolving under anti-inflammatory treatment.

Risti AD, Imazio M, Adler Y, et al. Triage strategy for urgent management of cardiac tamponade: a position statement of the European Society of Cardiology Working Group on Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases. European Heart Journal. 2014;35(34):2279-2284. https://doi.org/10.1093/eurheartj/ehu217
Small PE (< 1 cm in diastole), no trauma
Right atrial collapse > ⅓ of cardiac cycle
Urgent pericardiocentesis immediately after contraindications are ruled-out.
Pericardiocentesis can be postponed for up to 12/48 hours.

NOTE: Urgent surgical management is recommended regardless of the score for:
1. Type A aortic dissection
2. Ventricular free wall rupture after acute myocardial infarction
3. Severe recent chest trauma
4. Iatrogenic hemopericardium when the bleeding cannot be controlled percutaneously

preLBBBQTc = %1$d msec.

Use: Attempts to correct for the prolongation of the QT interval attributable to QRS prolongation in LBBB. 

Formula: preLBBBQTc = postLBBBQTc(Bazett) - postLBBBQRS + c, where c = 95 msec in males, 88 msec in females

Normal values: Presumably same as QTc.

Reference: %2$s

QRS duration must be at least 120 msec.

The calculator should not be used in patients with prior sustained ventricular arrhythmia or sudden cardiac arrest. It is designed to provide predictions based on the clinical characteristics of ARVC patients at time of their diagnosis.
